<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 211, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 211, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 0625/53 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 260, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2020 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 728, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 842]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 91, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 643, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 87, 576, 106]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 119, 908, 355]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 378, 532, 396]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 144, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 409, 180, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 409, 920, 442]]<|/det|> Ensure that the \(10.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the metre rule is immediately above the pivot and that the metre rule is suspended from the forcemeter at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 440, 833, 459]]<|/det|> **The metre rule should always be in this position before taking a reading.** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 472, 868, 504]]<|/det|> Move the \(200\mathrm{g}\) mass to a distance \(l = 20.0\mathrm{cm}\) from the pivot as shown in Fig. 1.1. Adjust the height of the clamp holding the pivot so that the metre rule is horizontal. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 517, 658, 536]]<|/det|> Read, and record in Table 1.1, the forcemeter reading \(F\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 549, 836, 567]]<|/det|> Repeat this procedure for values of \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(40.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(60.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 580, 539, 598]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 607, 598, 770]]<|/det|>
\(l/\text {cm}\)\(F/\text {N}\)
20.0
30.0
40.0
50.0
60.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 768, 920, 787]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Explain how you made sure that the metre rule was horizontal before each reading was taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 405, 120]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 304, 918, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 146, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 349, 566, 368]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(F / \mathsf{N}\) (y-axis) against \(l / \mathsf{cm}\) (x-axis).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 455, 383]]<|/det|>
Start your axes from the origin (0,0).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 399, 809, 778]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 787, 920, 804]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 185, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 665, 91]]<|/det|>
From your graph determine \(F_0\), the value of \(F\) when \(l = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<form>F_0 = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 133, 181, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 809, 152]]<|/det|>
Calculate the weight \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre rule, using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{R}} = 2 \times F_{0}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 147, 771, 166]]<|/det|>
Give \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 210, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
<form>W_{\mathrm{R}} = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
A student carrying out this experiment places the \(200\mathrm{g}\) mass on the metre rule instead of hanging it from the loop of thread.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 287, 688, 306]]<|/det|>
Suggest which of these is likely to be the more accurate method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 584, 322]]<|/det|>
Explain your answer by reference to the procedure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 427, 920, 445]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A student wants to determine \(R_{1}\) by using a variable resistor to control the current in the circuit. Complete the circuit in Fig. 2.4 to show a variable resistor connected for this purpose. You are not required to do this experiment.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 131, 734, 467]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 489, 534, 508]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 536, 180, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 535, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
Briefly explain how using the circuit in Fig. 2.4 will give a more reliable value for \(R_{1}\) than using the procedure you were asked to carry out in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 670, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 727, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment you will determine the focal length of a converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 576, 106]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 121, 907, 220]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 247, 532, 265]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 262, 203, 280]]<|/det|>
## Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 293, 144, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 293, 520, 312]]<|/det|>
Arrange the apparatus as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 324, 702, 343]]<|/det|>
Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated triangle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 355, 415, 373]]<|/det|>
Place the screen near the lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 386, 762, 405]]<|/det|>
Move the screen until a sharp image of the triangle is seen on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 416, 180, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 416, 858, 435]]<|/det|>
Measure the distance \(\nu\) between the lens and the screen as indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 448, 920, 466]]<|/det|>
<form>v = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 479, 180, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 479, 757, 497]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens. Use the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 505, 551, 533]]<|/det|>
\[f_{1} = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[574, 591, 920, 610]]<|/det|>
<form>f_{1} = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 205, 88]]<|/det|>
## Method 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 148, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Keep the screen in the same position so that the values of \(u\) and \(v\) are the same as in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 180, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 147, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
Move the lens closer to the screen until another sharp image of the triangle is seen on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 198, 255, 214]]<|/det|>
illuminated

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 214, 240, 231]]<|/det|>
triangle

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 228, 839, 310]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 336, 534, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 368, 920, 402]]<|/det|>
Measure the new distance \(u\) between the illuminated triangle and the lens as indicated in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 429, 917, 447]]<|/det|>
<form>\(u =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 460, 707, 479]]<|/det|>
Measure the new distance \(v\) between the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 491, 917, 510]]<|/det|>
<form>\(v =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 507, 920, 525]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 180, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 823, 541]]<|/det|>
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens. Use the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 549, 551, 578]]<|/det|>
\[f_{2} = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 599, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<form>\(f_{2} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 616, 203, 634]]<|/det|>
<label>Method 3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 647, 146, 665]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 647, 920, 665]]<|/det|>
Keep the screen in the same position so that the values of \(u\) and \(v\) are the same as in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 677, 181, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 677, 799, 695]]<|/det|>
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\), the height of the illuminated triangle, as indicated in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 708, 920, 727]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h_{\mathrm{O}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 739, 730, 757]]<|/det|>
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\), the height of the image of the triangle on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 771, 920, 789]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h_{\mathrm{I}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 785, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 817, 181, 835]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 812, 774, 835]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value \(M\) for the magnification, using the equation \(M = \frac{h_{\mathrm{I}}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<form>\(M =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 863, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 653, 90]]<|/det|>
Calculate a third value \(f_{3}\) for the focal length of the lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 85, 589, 104]]<|/det|>
Use your value of \(\nu\) from **(b)**(i) and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 103, 556, 133]]<|/det|>
\[f_{3} = \frac{\nu}{(M + 1)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 170, 920, 189]]<|/det|>
<form>f_{3} = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 201, 146, 219]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 201, 920, 234]]<|/det|>
State one precaution that you took to ensure that the measurements of \(u\) and \(v\) in this experiment are as reliable as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 144, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 310, 180, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 310, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
Explain why **Method 3** is likely to produce a less accurate value for the focal length than **Method 1**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 450, 180, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 450, 702, 467]]<|/det|>
Suggest one improvement to make **Method 3** more accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 567, 922, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the factors affecting the electrical output of a solar cell. A solar cell is a device which transforms light energy into electrical energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate how the potential difference across the terminals of the solar cell varies with the angle of the incident light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 522, 183]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 398, 214]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 418, 245]]<|/det|>
a solar cell as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 316, 259]]<|/det|>
a laboratory lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 324, 291]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 134, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 457, 322]]<|/det|>

<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 134, 432]]<|/det|>
